body:
Some investors say that a great team can make a business succeed even if the idea isn't great. On the flip side, a weak team can make a business fail even if the idea is great. 


So how can you work out what kind of people your business needs to succeed, find those people, convince them to join you and help them to thrive? 


By the end of this module, you will understand how to : 


  • Build a network of experienced mentors & advisors
  • Find and recruit your first employees
  • Understand your legal responsibilities are as an employer
title: Intro

body: This section summarises what mentors and advisors could bring to your team.
instruction: Click on the boxes below to find out.

_items.title: Who are they?
_items.body:
Mentors are people who support you as an individual on a regular, informal basis. They might encourage you personally, talk through key challenges and introduce you to relevant people.


Advisors are a group of supporters with highly relevant skills and experience. They support the organisation as a whole and you might meet 1:1 or as a group. They might give you regular advice or let you use their name to give you credibility.

_items.title: How can you find them?
_items.body:
Through extended networks of friends or family or by just asking people in the industry who you respect - be bold! 


For example, identify people who you think could help and attend industry events where they might be speaking or taking part. Ask them out for coffee and advice and see if they are interested in doing that on a regular basis.


You might use Linkedin and introduce yourself or contact people whose articles or blogs you have read. 


On a note of caution,  just because someone has been successful as a middle manager in a major corporation this may not equip them any better than you for the challenges of a fast-paced start-up.

_items.title: How can you reward them?
_items.body:
More often than you might think, people who have made it to the top of their field are looking for an opportunity to give back to people and organisations starting out. 


They may well also recognise that down the line, you might become a useful business contact or client for them.


If you are considering giving away equity, make sure that their advice will definitely add value to the business and it is only a small amount of equity. This should be by far the exception.

title: Accordion Title

body: As you move beyond the founding team, it is a major challenge to find complementary team members who share your passion and purpose and are willing to share the challenges of a perilous journey. Finding the right people is hard.
instruction: Click on the downward arrows below to walk through the 4 steps to hiring great people.

_items.body:
Plan the role by answering the following questions :


  • What will they need to achieve in the next 3 years and how will it be measured?
  • What soft skills and technical skills will they need? 
  • What culture are you trying to build in the organisation and what kind of person would fit in?
  • What qualifications would you expect them to have?
_items.title: Step 1 : Writing the job description

_items.body:
Many people find that personal networks are a great way to find high quality candidates. Networks like Linkedin, Facebook and Twitter can be a great way to get the word out.  


Start-up events, co-founder speed-dating events or start-up job boards like workinstartups.com could be a great way to meet candidates.
_items.title: Step 2 : Selecting the right people

_items.body:
Make sure each candidate speaks to more than one team member and that you assess them using the scorecard of what you are looking for. 


Chemistry is not enough! Many organisations find Skype or phone interviews a useful starting / screening point.
_items.title: Choosing the right people
Sell the role
_items.body:
Great people are likely to have multiple offers! Expect this to happen.


If you can't entice them with money, fear not. Think of the other things you can offer - mentoring, working with exceptional people, flexibility, high areas of responsibility from day 1, shares in the company and being part of something important.

title: Flow Chart Title

body: Here are the 6 legal responsibilities of an official employee. They should all be quite straightforward but it is important to know them!

_items.body: You must pay your employee at least the National Minimum Wage. It is strongly recommended that you pay at least the London Living Wage in London of £7.50/hour.
_items.title: Decide How much to pay
Check people's legal rights to work in the UK
_items.body: Check if someone has the legal right to work in the UK. You may have to do other employment checks as well.

_items.title: Get security clearance if needed
_items.body: Apply for a DBS check (formerly known as a CRB check) if you work in a field that needs one, e.g. with vulnerable people or security.
You need employers’ liability insurance as soon as you become an employer.
_items.title: Get employment insurance

_items.body: Send details of the job (including terms and conditions) in writing to your employee. You need to give your employee a written statement of employment if you’re employing someone for more than 1 month. In the playbook, there is a list of templates you could use.
_items.title: Give your employees written statement of employment

_items.body: Tell HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) by registering as an employer - you can do this up to 4 weeks before you pay your new staff. http://bit.ly/1WYVyBA
_items.title: Tell HMRC

title: Text and Graphic Title

body: How can you approach to recruiting mentors and advisors?
instruction: Choose 3 and click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


Most successful business leaders are happy to give back to promising entrepreneurs who make the most of their time with focused, well researched questions and people who show willingness to take their advice on board.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure that's right?


Most successful business leaders are happy to give back to promising entrepreneurs who make the most of their time with focused, well researched questions and people who show willingness to take their advice on board.

_items.text: Approach industry leaders who you particularly admire at conferences.
Contact thought leaders' whose blogs or articles you have read and found particularly helpful.
Offer advisers large proportions of your equity for giving you ad-hoc advice.
Contact organisations local business forums and ask if they know anyone with particular experience you are missing.

title: Q2-2-1

body: Put the steps to hiring a great candidate in order
instruction: Select a ranking number for each item and click submit.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


You write the job description, get the word out, interview with multiple colleagues, sell the role to your dream candidate and uphold your responsibilities as an employer.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


What normally happens is that you write the job description, get the word out, interview with multiple colleagues, sell the role to your dream candidate and uphold your responsibilities as an employer.

_items.text: Writing a detailed job description
Putting the word out, especially through your networks
Selecting the right candidate through interviews with multiple team members
Selling the role to the right candidate including its' non-financial benefits
Upholding your legal responsibilities as an employer

cancelButtonAriaLabel: This button cancels the current selected option
title: Q2-2-2

body: Which of the following is NOT an employer's legal requirement?
instruction: Select one answer and click submit.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Health checks are not part of an employer's legal responsibilities but the others are.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure? 


Health checks are not part of an employer's legal responsibilities but the others are.

_items.text: Paying employees the minimum wage
Checking employee's health history
Getting employee's liability insurance
Registering with HMRC as an employer
Getting a security check if the role is with vulnerable people
Checking someone's right to work in the UK
Sending employees a statement of employment within 1 month of starting

title: Q2-2-3

body:
To build up your team, you can start by building upwards with mentors and advisors. 


From there you can use the 4 step process to plan, source, screen and hire the right people for your team. 


Finally, you can ensure your team is well looked after and your ship is in order by upholding your 6 legal responsibilities as an employer.
displayTitle: You can build a winning team!
title: Building a Winning Team : Summary

body:
This module is all about taking your idea from something in your head and some models on scrap paper to an clearly explained idea that customers and investors can give you early feedback on. 


By the end of this module you will understand : 


  • How to check if your idea is worth acting one or holding out for a better one. 
  • How to plan a detailed and coherent proposition to customers by creating a pitch video, basic website and brochure
  • Draft a business plan to explain your offer to business partners and co-founders
title: Intro

body:
To make sure this idea is worth your time, it is worth just checking you can answer yes to these questions.


If you're not sure, don't hesitate to go through the idea generation and sorting process to find a concept you strongly believe could work in practice.


Your time and effort is valuable so it is best to spot any fatal flaws while you are still working on paper.

_items.title: clearly explain which problem I'm trying to solve for my customer?
list the main assumptions behind my business model?
say I've explored different business models using the ''canvas'' and chosen the one I think is best?

title: Am I ready to launch this idea?

_media._source: C2M2V1 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: Founders Stories: When did you take the jump?
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
body: Emma from Silkfred - a platform hosting independent fashion brands - talks about how she decided to make the jump.
title: Text Title

instruction: Click on the video to find out more
displayTitle: Founder Stories - When did you take the jump?
body: In this video, Josh the founder of Night Zookeeper - an interactive literacy tool for children - decided to make the jump.
title: Text Title

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222495881" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body:
A good way to check if your offering is clear and exciting to customers is to plan backwards. 


By making a set of promotional materials explaining to customer what you are offering, you will find any gaps in your concept and start thinking like a customer. 


3 great formats to lay out your customer proposition are: 


  • A pitch video
  • A basic website with key info 

  • A product brochure



So what should the materials aim to do? If your proposition is truly compelling, your materials should generate awareness, interest, desire and action.
displayTitle: How can I plan a solid offer for customers?
instruction: Click the video to find out more
title: Customer marketing materials

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222497078" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe><iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222497078" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body:
This 2-3 minute video brings your value proposition to life. You can share it on your homepage, e-brochure or in pitches.


They can be in lots of different formats and styles - ultimately, it is all about what will engage your customers most.
title: Text Title

instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Text Title

body:
Customers will expect you to have at least a basic website explaining what your idea is who you are and how they can stay updated. 


The good news is that you don't need any technical skills or money to do this. There are lots of free template website you can use to do this very simply and we have recommended a few in the resources section. 


When we talk about landing pages, it could be something as simple a page with a quick description and newsletter sign up box. 


The example to the left is a free design or ''theme'' you can use on a free Wordpress website. This one in particular is called ''construction website''.
title: Your Landing Page

body: The CTO of Amazon Werner Vogels blogged about the value of making promotional materials for a product that doesn't yet exist to help you plan.
displayTitle: Start by writing the Press Release
instruction: Click on the slides below to find out more.

_items.body: This should describe in a simple way what the product does and why it exists - what are the features and benefits? It should clarify how the world will see the product - not just how you think about it internally.
_items.title: Write a press release

_items.body: Put yourself in the shoes of someone reading the press release or using the product and consider all the questions you would have.
_items.title: Write a Frequently Asked Questions document
Write out a customer journey
_items.body:
Describe in precise detail the customer experience for different things they might do with the product e.g.: registering for the newsletter or buying a product. 


For products with a user interface, we would build mock-ups of each screen that the customer uses. 


For web services, we write use cases, including code snippets, which describe ways you can imagine people using the product. The goal here is to tell stories of how a customer is solving their problems using the product.

title: Start by writing the Press Release

displayTitle: How can I plan a solid offer for business partners?
instruction: Click on the slides below to find out more.
body: This section includes some suggested sections for your business plan. It aims to win over prospective colleagues and investors.

_items.body:
• Who should be on our management team?

  • What is the best organisational structure for this business?
_items.title: Executive Summary

_items.body: • What products will our customers want to buy?
_items.title: Details of the Problem/Solution

_items.body: • How will we make money?
_items.title: Your Business Model
Your Competitive Advantage
_items.body: • How will we make money?

_items.title: Marketing and Sales strategy
_items.body:
• Which customers should we target?
  • What products will our customers want to buy?

  • How should we distribute to communicate with our customers?

  • How can we protect our brand?

  • Which things should our company do, and which should our partners and suppliers do?

• Who are our competitors?

  • How are we better?

How will we know when to change course?
_items.title: Competitor analysis
Management team required
_items.body:
• Who are our competitors?

  • How are we better?

  • How will we know when to change course?

• Who should be on our management team?

  • What is the best organisational structure for this business?
_items.title: Financial projections and key metrics
Current status, accomplishments, timelines and use of funds?
_items.body:
• What have we achieved so far?
  • Whose investment capital will help, and whose might hurt?

title: Business Plan Template

_items.text: Can you clearly explain the customer's problem?

title: Q 2-1-1

body:
Your pitch video, website and brochure can help you to plan your offer for customers in detail. They are also helpful to win over your first customers. 


Which of the following is not a core aim of customer materials?

Well done! 


Customer materials should generate awareness, interest, desire and action.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Customer materials should generate awareness, interest, desire and action.

title: Q2-1-3

body:
You should now feel clear how to plan out your customer offer in detail, creating materials that will also help you to get feedback from early customers. 


You are also now ready to start drafting a business plan which will convince investors and future co-founders that your idea is likely to work. 


You are now well on your way to launching...
title: Text Title

body:
The best source of funding is always from selling your product - that way you don't owe anyone anything. For that reason, the less you can spend before you start to make money the better. This module is about being creative and bold to get a lot done on  a shoestring. By the end of this module, you will understand: 


  • What freebies and discounts you might be eligible for 
  • How you could get your first pot of money
  • What is important to funders when they think about investing 


We hope you will be positively surprised by how much can be done for free (or very little).
title: Text Title

body: There is a wealth of support available for entrepreneurs. Here are some potential shortcuts you might consider researching.
displayTitle: Bootstrapping - getting a lot done with a little
instruction: Click on the slides below to read more.

_items.body: Look for accelerators - these ''programmes'' all around the country offer mentoring, free office space and sometimes money to start-ups who they think are promising.
_items.title: Office Space

_items.body: Have you looked on freecycle for people giving things away? Could a post on Facebook unearth friends with spare chairs, printers and laptops lying around? Do you have any corporate partners who just so happen have been due to upgrade their old stock?
_items.title: Office furniture and supplies

_items.body: Local libraries and universities may well offer free business advice to start-ups. Legal firms often do pro-bono for start-ups in the hope that they will become clients down the line. In any case, it is always worth asking and offering a coffee. Perhaps you can help them in other ways? Fixing their website? Tutoring their kids? Helping out a charity they are passionate about?
_items.title: Advice

_items.body: The internet is full of free and low cost platforms and templates which you only need to customize  to make them ready to launch. Whether you are launching a marketplace, a crowdfunding website, an online shop or a community, check that there isn't a ready made template before paying to build your own.
_items.title: Basic websites

title: Narrative Title

body:
There is no doubt that the best source of funding is from paying customers. That said you might well need money to get to that point. 


Here is a brief summary of the main types of funding available and the section further down outlines what type you might go for at each stage of your business.
instruction: Click on the boxes below to find out more.

_items.title: Grants
_items.body:
Usually from charities or the government


PROS : This is ''free money'' you don't have to pay back. 


CONS : There may be strict rules on how you can spend it or a responsibility to submit detailed reports.

_items.title: Debt
_items.body:
This could be from banks or crowdfunding sources. 


PROS : Easy to get


CONS : It must be repaid (usually with interest) at a specific time and often requires some kind of security deposit from the founder or the business.

Funding in return for shares in your company. Traditionally from Business Angels and professional Venture Capital funds but increasingly from new models on platforms like PeopleFundIt or Crowdcube. 


PROS : Often comes with expertise and mentoring. 


CONS : Will want the opportunity to get a return on their investment so you will need to plan how you will eventually give them their money back, for example by selling the business. Other hybrid models include Convertible Instruments which start as a loan and convert into equity when the business reaches an agreed milestone.
_items.title: Equity

title: Different types of early funding

body: Here are the different phases of a business' growth and what kind of funding they might typically need.
instruction: Click on the boxes below to find out more

_items.title: Pre-seed
_items.body: This might typically be up to £50,000 and come in the form of grants or loans from family, friends or private investor. It could be that the entrepreneur themselves puts in the seed funding.
This might typically be up to 200K. It might come from specialist VCs with seed funds or private investors who would be looking for equity in return for the investment.
_items.title: Seed
Start-up
_items.body: This would typically be up to £2m and come from Venture Capitalists (Investors) working alone or in groups. They would request equity (shares) in exchange for the investment.

_items.title: Scale-up / Growth
_items.body: This would typically be for up to £5 million. It would come from mainstream Venture Capital firms or banks. They would be looking for equity or debt in exchange for their investment.

title: Stages of early funding

displayTitle: Founder Stories : Raising your first pot of money
body: In these videos, founders linked to the UCL ideashub share their experiences of raising their first pot of money.
instruction: Click on the video below to find out more.

_incorrect.body: Incorrect answer, click continue to try again
_incorrect.title: Incorrect

title: Founder Stories : Raising your first pot of money

displayTitle: What do funders usually look for?
instruction: Click on the slides below to find out more.
body: This section outlines some key criteria investors take into account when they meet entrepreneurs looking for money.

_items.title: Quality of the team
_items.body: Does the team have the skills, experience, networks and passion to execute on their plan?

_items.title: The scale of the opportunity
_items.body: Is this a market stall or a multinational opportunity?
What do you have that is Valuable, Rare, difficult to Imitate or difficult to Substitute? (VRIS)
_items.title: The potential to stay ahead of competition

_items.body: The momentum or “traction” - are you able to demonstrate that the team has made tangible, disciplined progress towards the reduction of key risks.
_items.title: Evidence of success

title: What funders look for

body: In these videos, UK entrepreneurs pitch to investors on the TV show Dragon's Den.
displayTitle: Investment in action : 3 UK start-ups pitch for investment
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Investment in action : 3 UK start-ups pitch for investment

body: Early stage start-ups should borrow as much money as possible initially as they will need a lot of cash to get going
instruction: Choose one then click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right.


The less money you need to borrow to get going, the less money you will owe down the line and can hold onto all your equity.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


The less money you need to borrow to get going, the less money you will owe down the line and can hold onto all your equity.

_items.text: True
False

title: Q2-3-1

body: Which type of funding is best described as
instruction: Choose one and click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Grant funding doesn't need to be paid back, equity funding is given in exchange for shares and debt funding is loans which need to be paid back with interest.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure that's right? 


Grant funding doesn't need to be paid back, equity funding is given in exchange for shares and debt funding is loans which need to be paid back with interest.

_items.text: Money that doesn't need to be paid back but often has to be spent in very specific ways.
Money from a bank for example that needs to be paid back with interest by a specific date.
Funding which is given in exchange for a stake in the business and must be paid back in the long run.

title: Q2-3-2

body: Which of the following features are less important than the others?
instruction: Choose one answer then click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Academic record is often less important that the other criteria.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Academic record is often less important that the other criteria.

_items.text: A team who they are convinced can deliver on the vision
A strong academic record
The potential for the business to grow into a large scale operation
How hard the business would be to imitate
Any evidence of early business success

title: Q2-3-3

body:
To launch your business on a shoestring, use as many free or low-cost resources as possible. Don't be afraid to ask and be creative about what you can offer in return! 


If you need extra funding, think about the option that suits you best - from equity, loan or grant funding. There are dozens of accelerators across the UK who can help you get off the ground in exchange of equity or cash investment.


When you ask for funding, focus on the things that matter to them including the quality of your team, the scalability of your business and any early evidence of success.
title: Summary

body:
Now that you have a clear idea what you are offering to customers, it is time to leave the building and try to find your first customers. By the end of this module you will understand :  


  • Choose which customers to reach out to first. 
  • Plan your sales as a ''funnel''
  • Track key information about your sales process so you can make good decisions about what to do next.
title: Text Title

body: In this series of videos, the team at UCL business incubator IDEALONDON share some tips on choosing your first customers.
displayTitle: Who should your first customers be?

_incorrect.body: Incorrect answer, click continue to try again
_incorrect.title: Incorrect

title: Who should your first customers be?

displayTitle: The diffusion of innovation - who will your early adopters be?

_items.body: People who actively seek out new products to try - 'hackers' who are keen to work with even partially completed products.
_items.title: Innovators

_items.body: Visionaries who are keen to get ahead of the herd, they are actively looking for new products or services that can make their lives better.
_items.title: Early Adopters
Early Majority
_items.body: The first of our mainstream customers if we are going to reach significant scale. These are the pragmatists who want to 'Stick with the herd'. They seek innovation but don't want anything that is too threatening to their business as usual.

_items.title: Late Majority
_items.body: These more conservatives buyers need a lot of convincing to switch to new solutions - they need to be sure that they are buying into a mature and robust product or service.

_items.title: Laggards
_items.body: There are always some who will only buy on the basis of price rather than improved or enhanced capability.

title: Narrative Title

body:
You may have developed fantastic products and services but ultimately you need to be able to close sales with customers.


In order to do this, you need a structured, repeatable model for acquiring customers otherwise your growth will be limited.


There are lots of ways you can chart a customer's journey from being a stranger to being a repeat buyer but in this module, we'll look at a classic sales funnel - a four stage process explained below in more detail below.
displayTitle: Making sales a process : The Funnel
title: Making sales a process : The Funnel

displayTitle: How to move customers through the funnel
body: In the flow chart below, we look at 4 steps to moving customers through the funnel - Prospecting, Cultivating, Positioning and Closing.

_items.title: Step 1 : Prospecting
_items.body:
Identifying potential customers to target with our sales and marketing message. 


This could involve buying lists of prospects or professional membership lists or looking for lists of companies on the Companies House website who might need your product.


You might also generate lists of prospects from social networks or online communities. 


If you are selling straight to the general public rather than another company, you might targeted adverts to specific customer segments through online advertising platforms such as Facebook and Google Adwords.

_items.title: Step 2 : Cultivating
_items.body:
In the ''cultivating' phase, you can target qualified prospects, the 'suspects' who have engaged with initial marketing outreach. They might have been referred from another customer or reached out directly (e.g. at exhibitions or events). 


In this phase we seeking to confirm that our business can solve their problem. This phase might happen in a meeting or a phone call but it could happen without your intervention as a customer looks up your website and reads your materials.
This is where we demonstrate how our solution meets the stated needs of the customer and why it does this better than our competitors.
_items.title: Step 3 : Positioning
Step 4 : Closing
_items.body: The conversion of a prospect to a customer.

title: Sales funnel

body:
As you manage multiple customer through multiple steps for the sales journey, it is important to stay organised.


A dashboard is a good way for you to decide what data to track and how to present it so you can get an instant snapshot of how you are doing with sales and where you need to focus your efforts. In this video, the team from IDEALONDON explain more.


In the Resources section, we recommend some tools like Google Analytics to help you gather this data straight from your website.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222497985" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

title: Video Stream Title

body:
Metrics should help you to make decisions and are closely linked to revenue and profit. E.g.: number of active users, user engagement or customer acquisition costs (and ultimately revenues and profit).


Other metrics might be tempting because they are easier to grow and make you feel good! e.g. registered users, app downloads or raw page views. These are called vanity metrics. 


Good metrics not only help you to stay focused, they give you an insight into whether customers are responding well to your offer and whether your product needs changing.  


Good metrics should be :

_items.title: Actionable : What will you do differently based on this information?
Comparative : Can I compare it against performance in an equivalent time period e.g.: This time last year?
Understandable : Are these clear enough that I could have a conversation about them with everyone on the team from interns to investors?

title: Good metrics vs Vanity metrics

body: When should you start selling?
instruction: Choose 2 answers and click submit.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


The sooner you can get feedback from real customers, the better.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Getting customer feedback and sign-ups from early innovators as soon as possible is the best place to start. Don't wait for perfection!

_items.text: When your product is perfect
Once you have customer-facing materials even if you don't have a product yet
When you have a basic prototype

title: Q2-4-1

body: Put the steps of the sales process into the right order.
instruction: Click on each item and choose a ranking

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


The sales process goes from  Prospecting to Cultivating, Positioning and Closing

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


The sales process goes from Prospecting to Cultivating, Positioning and Closing

_items.text: Prospecting : Identifying potential customers to target with sales & marketing message
Positioning : Checking that we understand the prospect's problem, for example through meetings. Explaining to prospective customers how our solution solves their problem
Cultivating : Explaining to prospective customers how our solution solves their problem
Closing : Converting prospects into a customer and achieving a sale.

cancelButtonAriaLabel: This button cancels the current selected option
title: Q2-4-2

body: Classify the following metrics as ''actionable metrics'' and and ''vanity metrics''
instruction: Drag the items into the correct box and click submit.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Good metrics are actionable, comparative and understandable.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Good metrics are actionable, comparative and understandable.

_items.text: Number of visitors to a landing page
Number of sales from a trade show
Number of pre-orders from the landing page
Number of calls made

title: Q2-4-3

body:
You now know to start with people who are actively searching for a solution to a problem that you can help them with. You know that ''Innovators'' will be the best people to win over first. 


You also know how to set up a repeatable sales process as a funnel and move customers through the funnel by prospecting, cultivating, positioning and closing leads. 


Finally you know how to gather and analyse your sales data by choosing meaningful metrics that show you are moving towards increased revenues (rather than falling into the trap of tracking vanity metrics).
title: Summary

body:
In this module, we cover the things you need to do to make your business official. By the end of this module, you will understand how to :


  • Decide how to allocate co-founder shares 
  • Register your company legally in the form that is right for you 
  • Fulfil your legal responsibilities as a company director
title: Text Title

displayTitle: Deciding how to split the equity between co-founders
body:
This can be an awkward conversation but it is best to do it early. If you can't get through that, you might not be ready to face the bigger hurdles which will inevitably come.

In our resources section, we have included a template that might be a useful starting point.
instruction: Click on the video below to find out more

_incorrect.body: Incorrect answer, click continue to try again
_incorrect.title: Incorrect

title: Interactive Video Title

body:
Although you can start selling without being a registered business, it is often best to register early on.


Some benefits are making sure you don't have any personal liabilities and being more credible to customers and business partners.


All you need to register is names of shareholders, an official address where you can receive mail, £15 and a unique company name. You can do this on the companies house website.


As part of registering, you will need to draft up a company ''Rulebook'' called ''articles of memorandum''. This could be adapted from a standard template to include clauses around who owns which shares and any conditions around investment locked into the business in case, for example someone leaves or doesn't deliver on their promises. The articles aren't set in stone and you can change them as new investors come on board.
displayTitle: When and how to register your business
title: Setting up your company officially

body: You will also need to decide what structure of company you want to be.
instruction: Click on the slides for an overview of the options

_items.title: Sole Trader
_items.body: A single person operating as a business. It’s simpler to set up as a sole trader, but you’re personally responsible for your business’s debts. You also have some accounting responsibilities.

_items.title: Limited Company
_items.body:
If you form a limited company, its finances are separate from your personal finances, but there are more reporting and management responsibilities.


A for-profit business with shares - the most common type of business is called a CLS or ''company limited by shares''


A non-profit business e.g.: A sports club can be set up as a company limited by guarantee. 


Some people get help from a professional e.g.: From an accountant to set up a limited company but you can set up a yourself.

Whilst all businesses make more revenue than they spend, not all are seeking to maximise profits as their ultimate goal. Social Enterprise UK defines social enterprises as :


'Businesses that trade to tackle social problems, improve communities, people’s life chances, or the environment. They make their money from selling goods and services in the open market, but they reinvest their profits back into the business or the local community'.


These could be set up as 


  • Charities
  • Community Interest Companies 
  • Company Limited by Guarantee


For more information, see the Resources section.
_items.title: Social Enterprise
Partnerships
_items.body:
A partnership is the simplest way for 2 or more people to run a business together.


You share responsibility for your business’s debts. You also have accounting responsibilities. Find out more about being in a partnership and how to register.

title: Types of businesses

body: As a director, you have several legal responsibilities.
instruction: Click on the boxes to find out what they are

_items.title: Must act in good faith in the interest of the company
_items.body: E.g. you must not pursue a course of action that might benefit you personally (or others) at the expense of the company

_items.title: Are legally responsible for the actions of a company
_items.body: Are responsible under law for the actions of the company and in some circumstances may be liable to losses arising from their actions (ignorance is no defence!)
This should include the preparation of annual statement of accounts for Companies House
_items.title: Must ensure the keeping of adequate accounting records
Must ensure that the company does not trade whilst insolvent
_items.body: This is your legal responsibility as a director! You could face serious consequences including bans from opening companies in the future.

title: Legal responsibilities of a director

body: Which of the following statements is false?
instruction: Select your answer then click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's Right! 


You can change articles of memorandum as shareholders join and leave the team.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


You can change articles of memorandum as shareholders join and leave the team.

_items.text: All you need to register a company is £15, names of directors, an address and a unique company name
Articles of association are a ''rulebook'' for founders and investors about who owns which shares and how that might change at future milestones
Articles of association are set in stone - you cannot change them
When you register you need to choose what kind of business you want to be

title: Q2-5-1

body: Is the following statements true or false?
instruction: Choose the correct answer then click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Although it might feel awkward, it is important to sort out founder equity early to avoid conflict down the line.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure? 


Although it might feel awkward, it is important to sort out founder equity early to avoid conflict down the line.

_items.text: Deciding on equity early on isn't important, it is recommended to wait until you have investment to discuss it properly.

title: Q2-5-2

body: Which of the following is not a legal responsibility of directors?
instruction: Select an answer and click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


It is often the responsibility of a director to decide on CEO's salaries but not necessarily.

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure? 


It is often the responsibility of a director to decide on CEO's salaries but not necessarily.

_items.text: Acting in the best interest of the company
Submitting annual accounts to companies house
Making sure the company doesn't trade while insolvent
Ensuring the CEO's remuneration is fair
Making sure the company operates within the law

title: Q2-5-3

body: Good work! You now have the tools to decide on share allocation with your co-founders, register with Companies' House and live up to your role as a director. The resources section of this module has more information and detail if you need it.
title: Summary
